meta.title: [Pending Translation] Epoch Time Converter - Unix Timestamp to Date & Date to Timestamp
meta.description: [Pending Translation] Convert Unix Epoch timestamps to human-readable dates and vice versa. Support for local time, GMT/UTC, and relative time with our free, instant converter.
meta.subtitle: [Pending Translation] Convert Unix timestamps to human-readable dates and vice versa

content.hero_description: [Pending Translation] Unix time (or Epoch time) is the system checking the heartbeat of the digital world. It tracks the number of seconds that have elapsed since the "Unix Epoch" — 00:00:00 UTC on 1 January 1970.
content.efficiency_desc: [Pending Translation] Computers prefer simple integers over complex date strings. It's faster to process and store.
content.universal_desc: [Pending Translation] It ignores timezones during storage. 1696516200 is the same moment in Tokyo as it is in New York.
content.math_desc: [Pending Translation] Calculating the difference between two dates is as simple as simple subtraction (A - B).
content.code_title: [Pending Translation] Get Current Epoch in Your Language
content.apocalypse_desc: [Pending Translation] On January 19, 2038, 32-bit systems will run out of numbers to store the time, causing the "Unix Y2K". Most modern 64-bit systems are already safe for the next 292 billion years.

meta.title: [Pending Translation] Time Unit Converter - Seconds, Minutes, Hours
meta.description: [Pending Translation] Convert time durations instantly. Seconds to minutes, hours to days, weeks to months, and years.
meta.subtitle: [Pending Translation] Convert seconds, minutes, hours, days, weeks & years

content.feature1_desc: [Pending Translation] Convert between seconds, minutes, hours, days, weeks, months, and years.
content.feature2_desc: [Pending Translation] Perfect for scheduling, video editing, project timelines, and time tracking.
content.feature3_desc: [Pending Translation] Accurate time conversions for science, programming, and daily planning.
content.description_p1: [Pending Translation] Time is measured in various units depending on the scale: seconds for short durations, minutes and hours for daily activities, days for short periods, and weeks, months, and years for longer spans. The SI base unit is the second, defined by atomic clock precision. Understanding time conversions is essential for scheduling, programming, project management, and scientific calculations.
content.description_p2: [Pending Translation] One minute equals 60 seconds, one hour equals 3,600 seconds, and one day equals 86,400 seconds. There are 168 hours in a week and approximately 730 hours in a month. These conversions become crucial when working with different time scales, converting between formats, or calculating durations across various contexts.
content.usage_1: [Pending Translation] Project Management: Converting work hours to days or weeks
content.usage_2: [Pending Translation] Video Editing: Converting timestamps between formats
content.usage_3: [Pending Translation] Programming: Millisecond to second conversions for timers
content.usage_4: [Pending Translation] Science: Measuring reaction times in experiments
content.usage_6: [Pending Translation] Travel: Calculating trip durations across time zones
content.faq_q1: [Pending Translation] How many seconds are in a day?
content.faq_a1: [Pending Translation] There are exactly 86,400 seconds in one day (24 hours × 60 minutes × 60 seconds = 86,400 seconds).
content.faq_q2: [Pending Translation] How do I convert hours to days?
content.faq_a2: [Pending Translation] Divide the number of hours by 24. For example, 48 hours ÷ 24 = 2 days. Our converter handles this automatically!
content.faq_q3: [Pending Translation] Why is a year 365.25 days?
content.faq_a3: [Pending Translation] Earth's orbit takes approximately 365.25 days, which is why we have leap years every 4 years to add the extra quarter day and keep calendars aligned with seasons.
content.faq_q4: [Pending Translation] What's the difference between duration and time?
content.faq_a4: [Pending Translation] Time refers to a specific moment (e.g., 3:00 PM), while duration measures how long something lasts (e.g., 2 hours). This converter handles duration conversions.

meta.title: [Pending Translation] Time Zone Converter - Global Meeting Planner
meta.description: [Pending Translation] Visualize time differences across the globe. Compare times between two cities or zones side-by-side. Ideal for arranging international meetings.
meta.subtitle: [Pending Translation] Convert time between different timezones worldwide accurately

content.hero_desc: [Pending Translation] Schedule meetings, catch flights, and coordinate across continents without the headache. Our converter handles all the math.
content.business_desc: [Pending Translation] Avoid the embarrassment of calling a client at 3 AM.
content.travel_desc: [Pending Translation] Know exactly when your flight lands in local time.
content.events_desc: [Pending Translation] Don't miss the start of a global livestream.
content.tip1_desc: [Pending Translation] Daylight Saving Time rules vary by country and change dates every year. Automatic converters are safer than mental math.
content.tip2_desc: [Pending Translation] It removes ambiguity between AM and PM (e.g., is 12:00 midnight or noon?).
content.tip3_desc: [Pending Translation] When calling across the Pacific (e.g., US to Australia), it is often already tomorrow on the other side.
content.faq_q1: [Pending Translation] Are GMT and UTC the same?
content.faq_a1: [Pending Translation] For most practical purposes, yes. UTC is the precise atomic standard, while GMT is the older solar-based standard. They are within a fraction of a second of each other.
content.faq_q2: [Pending Translation] Why do some zones have 30 or 45 minute offsets?
content.faq_a2: [Pending Translation] Political and geographical reasons. India (UTC+5:30) and Nepal (UTC+5:45) chose these offsets to better align solar noon with their longitude.
